title: Markets Downplay Tariff Talk; Mizuho CEO Masahiro Kihara | Bloomberg Daybreak: Asia Edition

rawLines.text: [Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
Welcome to the Daybreak Asia podcast.
I'm Doug Krer. We begin with a story
dominating much of the news cycle,
tariffs. Today, President Trump seemed
to be sending mixed signals when it
comes to levies on European goods. He
said there's still room for trade talks
with the EU. But Trump also insisted the
letters he recently sent outlining new
tariff rates are final. Well, markets
seem to look past the rhetoric, US
equities pushed higher. And in a moment,
we'll look at the tariff story from the
Asian perspective. And part of our
conversation with the CEO of Mizahu,
Masahiro Kihara, but we begin here in
the States. Joining me now is Carol
Schlife. She is the chief market
strategist at Beimo Private Wealth.
Carol is on the line from Chicago. Good
of you to make time to chat with me. Can
we look ahead to the earnings that we're
expecting this week from the big banks?
I'm curious as to what you're expecting.
Expecting good earnings because you
actually saw it in the first quarter
already. You saw trading volumes doing
very well. You've seen M&A pick up.
We'll be listening closely too for the
commentary around the health of the
consumer and I think they'll be there's
a lot of great data coming out this week
and having the banks kick things off
will be really interesting to watch
that. But you've also got loosened
capital requirements. So you've
basically got a lot of money burning
holes in big bank pockets and I'll want
to listen to and see how they're
intending to use that.
What about the trading revenue side of
the equation given a lot of the market
volatility that we had in Q2? I would
imagine that some of these results will
be pretty robust.
Yeah, I would think that because we saw
surprises already in the first quarter
and that was before the April 2nd and
all of the subsequent trading. And when
you think through, if you remember back
to that time, there was one point in
time where we went down 5% to up 5% all
based on rumor and take away the rumor
all in the same day. And that trading
revenue will all come into this quarter.
So I mentioned the tariff story a moment
ago. Tomorrow we get CPI here in the US
and the big question is whether or not
we're going to begin to see evidence
that companies are passing along those
higher cost of imported uh goods
merchandise associated with the tariffs.
Would that be your expectation? I would
think we're going to see it more in the
PPI than the CPI at this point. And we
might be a quarter or two or not
necessarily a quarter or two, we might
be a month or two away from seeing it
creep through into the CPI because
you've got in a big way because you've
had a lot of companies do they brought
it over, they hoarded it, they've
absorbed it pretty well, but that's
wearing pretty thin. And so it as as
opposed to looking to the aggregate
numbers for it, I think we'll be looking
over the next couple weeks and listening
really closely to what the companies are
all saying, particularly the consumer
goods companies and how they're able to
either absorb it or pass it on.
There was some new research uh today
coming out of 22V research about uh what
investor expectations are for the
average effective tariff rate when the
dust settles. that number is 17%. That
seems pretty high. Would that cause you
to kind of take a closer look at a lot
of the holdings that you have on the
equity side?
Not necessarily a closer look, but um we
think it's pretty absorbable and markets
markets may not be quite that high. They
might be more like 12 or 13%. But, you
know, it's just it's important that we
don't lose sight because I know the
administration is very positive about
look at all the tariff revenues that are
coming in and it's important we not lose
sight that those tariff revenues are
coming out of either consumer or
business pockets in the United States
and sooner or later that's going to wear
away at the margins even if it's in
slightly slower growth or or moderately
slower growth. I think the issue would
be the market is not prepared for
broader sectoral tariffs and we have a
shot at getting some of those. I think
maybe there's partial
ex expectation too that the longer we
push out these full country tariffs, the
likelier we are to see some sort of
legal overturning because the testimony
in those in that case starts in I think
it's July 31st. So, I'm wondering
whether the the uncertainty around
tariffs and the impact in terms of the
inflationary impact or the inflationary
pressure that these tariffs may create
really keeps the Fed on the sidelines
for perhaps longer than a period that
would take us through September. Um, our
expectation is still in September and
you may see enough continued wear and
tear on the economy by then that the Fed
feels compelled to go ahead and move
because they're not necessarily going to
wait for hard data to come through. And
by the time we get to September, you
will have you'll have a couple more CPI
prints, a couple more PPI prints, you'll
have some data for the Fed to start
looking at. And we do think you'll see a
continued um deceleration, if you will.
We're not looking, we don't think it's
recessionary, but we do think that
you're impacting the strong growth we
came into January with.
I want to focus a little bit, if we can,
on one industry in particular,
artificial intelligence. Today, Mark
Zuckerberg said that Meta is going to be
building massive data centers to power
AI. Elon Musk saying that Tesla
shareholders will be voting soon on
whether to invest in Musk's startup XAI.
And tomorrow in Pennsylvania, President
Trump will be announcing a $70 billion
investment package that will focus not
only on AI but energy generation as
well. Are you still playing this? And if
if so, how is that unfolding in your
portfolio? I think it's hard not to play
it, if you will, in terms of I mean just
owning a plain old index fund and any of
the technology names and you're you're
at least market weighted if not
overweighted in in that play. And yeah,
we do think the combination of that and
some of the more progrowth, pro
businessfriendly aspects of the one big
beautiful bill that was passed last week
or the week before, those things do put
some nice support underneath. So that's
one of the reasons why we're not out
there with a massive recessionary fall.
And that could help surprise relative to
employment, too, because you've got
tighter labor markets in there. And if
you get some support where companies are
hiring again, because they need to hire
for construction workers. They're going
to need to pay those workers a little
more than they historically have, if you
will. We're going to put up those data
centers, leverage AI across a variety of
industries, and we don't think it's
close to the final innings. It's
definitely in the early innings still in
terms of the build out there in much the
same way as you're probably in the mid
90s, not the late 90s when we were
building out the infrastructure for the
internet to begin with.
The other thing that's happened under
the Trump administration is this
embracing of cryptocurrencies.
House Republicans have declared this
week as crypto week. We've got three
bills on the agenda on the House side.
Maybe uh a regulatory framework begins
to emerge and maybe some institutional
investor appetite begins to occur around
crypto. And as I'm speaking to you,
Carol, Bitcoin is above 120,000, which
is hard to believe because when
President Trump was elected to his
second term, I think Bitcoin was under
70,000. So, this has been a pretty
phenomenal run and I'm curious as to how
you're feeling about it.
It's interesting. It's something we've
watched. It still feels like it's in the
speculative zone pieces of it, but build
again building out the infrastructure of
it, watching it play, having a
regulatory framework of it will help.
And I think we need to pick a handful of
industries that we want to make sure we
stay at the forefront of. and you know
trying to bring some battery technology
back whether it's restarting some of the
nuclear energy because it's one thing
all of this stuff is going to take
energy on the grid and we're not going
to get there just by um pumping oil and
drilling coal.
Okay, Carol, we'll leave it there. Thank
you so very much. Carol Schlife, she is
the chief market strategist at Beimo
Private Wealth joining us here on the
Daybreak Asia podcast.
[Music]
Welcome back to the Daybreak Asia
podcast. I'm Doug Krner. The CEO of
Japan's third largest bank says the US
will continue to be an important trading
partner for Japan even with tariff
uncertainty. Still, Mizuo CEO Masahiro
Kihara says Japan will need to diversify
away from its second biggest trading
partner. Kihara spoke with Bloomberg's
Francine Lqua in London. Here is part of
their conversation. Mr. Kihara, thank
you so much for speaking to us here at
Bloomberg. Now, how confident are you
about reaching the 1 trillion yen profit
within a few years given all of the
global uncertainty and given what we
heard on tariffs and trade?
Thank you very much for having me. Uh,
in fact, I think from uh uh current uh
earning profile, I think we have almost
reached 1 trillion yen actually. uh we
we had 800 last year we had 880 billion
uh we took onetime losses around
somewhere around 120 billion actually so
I think uh in reality we we reached one
trillion thanks for all the you know uh
circumstances
but but what does the uncertainty do the
the uncertainty surrounding some of the
Trump policies and trade and tariffs
yes yes so before April 2nd we were
aiming somewhere around 1.1 trillion
yen for this year actually. However,
because of all the uncertainties, we uh
sort of shrink it down from as a
conservative base to uh 950 trillion uh
I'm sorry, 950 billion again. But I
think you know uh when things get
certain the the corporate action will
come back which means that we can
ratchet up a little bit. Yeah. Or
guidance.
So So where are you seeing that
uncertainty play into right now? Is it
loans? Is it chief executives not
spending, not deploying cash?
Yes. Right now the the CEOs are very
very on the sidelines actually
but uh uh but for for example if it is a
domestic deal uh even in each region if
it is a domestic deal things are
happening which means that we don't see
a lot of crosswater happening right now.
All of them are we have a big uh chunk
of pipeline but they they're not
executed but from a domestically
perspective people are moving a little
bit. So I think you know there is a a
good chance that uh people will get
confident at some point.
You you've also built up um a a US
investment bank basically franchise.
How's that going?
So we starting from building the capital
markets by oursel we went to equity
capital markets. M&A was missing for us
but we purchased Green Hill and I think
at this moment we have the necessary
pieces on the ground actually. So uh I'm
very very uh looking forward to see uh
the synergies between our former miso
platform and the green hill platform to
materialize actually.
But do you plan to take the the model of
the successful investment bank that you
built and actually apply it elsewhere
including in Asia?
Yes. So uh we would like to uh
uh sort of use our uh US capabilities
transplanted to Europe, Asia and so that
the re also even in in Japan
so that there will be cross regional
collaboration between uh regions and so
that and that I think that will uh bring
our next growth actually. How much of
your growth will be organic and how much
will be through mergers and
acquisitions?
From now on, uh I think we did the green
hill deal. It's uh very important that
we uh make sure that the synergies will
be built out and and and for for us the
next growth will basically be organic.
Okay. because you've said in the past
that you weren't used to or you didn't
want to for example um interested in
buying some you know traditional
commercial banks with a physical branch
network. So that's still the case.
That's still the case.
That's still the case.
But how do you see Mitso changing
actually in the next four to five years?
Yeah. So I I mean there are a couple of
areas that should be interesting for us.
uh just as I said uh investment banking
regional collaboration that will bring a
lot of uh synergies inside our uh
institution also as as you may know
asset management wealth management is uh
uh growing in Japan and this will be
another area and also one of one more
area that will be very interesting will
will be Japanese midcaps actually
okay
so the midcaps are keen to grow or if
they cannot grow they they might delist
And these there are couple uh many
corporate actions happening in that
space. So I think this will be another
interesting area for us. I
is competition very fierce in in wealth
management.
Yes. Uh it is very a high competitive
but but uh uh I think the thing is is
that the overall market is growing and
that is beneficial for all of the banks
I think. Yeah.
And on the midcap is there something
specific? Will it be basically lending
that they need or all services as they
grow?
There will be advisories.
Yeah.
And also lending. So both.
How do you see the you know Japanese
landscape for businesses changing? H how
much will they look? I mean Japan has
been a great experiment right in terms
of financials for a long time.
Yes.
Is it companies that will then grow also
abroad as the economy stabilizes? I
would say that uh if right now there's
many uncertainties but uh I think as
things get clearer
uh the corporate action will come back
uh uh these couple of years we have seen
many corporate actions happening uh
investing outside Japan
uh you know changing their business
portfolio risk
selling parts of the business that they
are not doing well so concentrating the
areas that have strength banks. So I I I
would say that once things get clear uh
corporate action will come back and many
you know uh uh Japanese corporates will
try to invest in outside of Japan too.
Are are you confident in the Japanese
economy overall?
Overall I think uh we still have
strengths in the uh uh uh economy
sectors that we uh have. So I think
overall uh we are very I am very
confident in that.
Uh the thing is that we we have to
concentrate our resources in the area
that we have strength.
Uh we have high quality manufacturing uh
high quality uh uh you know uh products.
Uh so I think we need to figure out
where the uh strengths are and try to
sell it to the uh to the world. Do do
you worry or are there dangers actually
to Japan given the spike in long-term
interest rates?
Yes. So 20 years
so for the long end uh I suppose 20
years 30 years uh there has been spike
and there has been volatility but I
think the government said that they will
try to shift the issuance to a 10 years
or below. I think the BOJ is a little
bit shrinking it uh QT. I think that
will help.
But is there a point where it actually
starts hurting your business and starts
hurting the real economy?
Well, I think uh BOJ is saying that the
neutral rate is somewhere around 1 1% to
1.5%. And on top of that uh 10 years
will be somewhere around 2 to 2.25%.
Then I think that that's the level that
is uh okay. But if it goes beyond to 3%
or so that will then hurt the budget. I
think
are are you expecting more more turmoil
in you know in yen but also not in the
bond market
not at this at this moment actually I
think the current level of 1.4 before
1.5 for 10 years is very uh it's okay I
think uh
you know and we have I I I I haven't
seen any turmoil in the 10 years zone so
as long as the 10 year is fine I think
it's fine
that is Masahiro Kihara the CEO of miso
speaking with Bloomberg's Francine Lqua
here on the Daybreak Asia podcast
[Music]
thanks for listening to today's episode
of the Bloomberg Daybreak Asia edition
podcast each weekday we look at the
stories is shaping markets, finance, and
geopolitics in the Asia-Pacific. You can
find us on Apple, Spotify, the Bloomberg
Podcast YouTube channel, or anywhere
else you listen. Join us again tomorrow
for insight on the market moves from
Hong Kong to Singapore and Australia.
I'm Doug Krer, and this is Bloomberg.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts,
radio, news.
Welcome to the Daybreak Asia podcast.
I'm Doug Krer.
We begin with a story dominating much of the news cycle, tariffs.
Today, President Donald Trump seemed to be sending mixed signals when it comes to levies on European goods.
He said there's still room for trade talks with the EU.
But Trump also insisted the letters he recently sent outlining new tariff rates are final.
Well, markets seem to look past the rhetoric, US equities pushed higher.
And in a moment, we'll look at the tariff story from the Asian perspective and part of our conversation with the CEO of Mizuho, Masahiro Kihara, but we begin here in the States.
Joining me now is Carol Schleif.
She is the Chief Market Strategist at BMO Private Wealth.
Carol is on the line from Chicago.
Good of you to make time to chat with me.
Can we look ahead to the earnings that we're expecting this week from the big banks?
I'm curious as to what you're expecting.
Expecting good earnings because you actually saw it in the first quarter already.
You saw trading volumes doing very well.
You've seen M&A pick up.
We'll be listening closely too for the commentary around the health of the consumer and I think there'll be a lot of great data coming out this week and having the banks kick things off will be really interesting to watch that.
But you've also got loosened capital requirements.
So you've basically got a lot of money burning holes in big bank pockets and I'll want to listen to and see how they're intending to use that.
What about the trading revenue side of the equation given a lot of the market volatility that we had in Q2?
I would imagine that some of these results will be pretty robust.
Yeah, I would think that because we saw surprises already in the first quarter and that was before the April 2nd and all of the subsequent trading.
And when you think through, if you remember back to that time, there was one point in time where we went down 5% to up 5% all based on rumor and take away the rumor all in the same day.
And that trading revenue will all come into this quarter.
So I mentioned the tariff story a moment ago.
Tomorrow we get CPI here in the US and the big question is whether or not we're going to begin to see evidence that companies are passing along those higher cost of imported goods merchandise associated with the tariffs.
Would that be your expectation?
I would think we're going to see it more in the PPI than the CPI at this point.
And we might be a quarter or two or not necessarily a quarter or two, we might be a month or two away from seeing it creep through into the CPI because you've got in a big way because you've had a lot of companies do they brought it over, they hoarded it, they've absorbed it pretty well, but that's wearing pretty thin.
And so as opposed to looking to the aggregate numbers for it, I think we'll be looking over the next couple weeks and listening really closely to what the companies are all saying, particularly the consumer goods companies and how they're able to either absorb it or pass it on.
There was some new research today coming out of 22V research about what investor expectations are for the average effective tariff rate when the dust settles.
That number is 17%.
That seems pretty high.
Would that cause you to kind of take a closer look at a lot of the holdings that you have on the equity side?
Not necessarily a closer look, but we think it's pretty absorbable and markets may not be quite that high.
They might be more like 12 or 13%.
But, you know, it's just it's important that we don't lose sight because I know the administration is very positive about look at all the tariff revenues that are coming in and it's important we not lose sight that those tariff revenues are coming out of either consumer or business pockets in the United States and sooner or later that's going to wear away at the margins even if it's in slightly slower growth or or moderately slower growth.
I think the issue would be the market is not prepared for broader sectoral tariffs and we have a shot at getting some of those.
I think maybe there's partial expectation too that the longer we push out these full country tariffs, the likelier we are to see some sort of legal overturning because the testimony in those in that case starts in I think it's July 31st.
So, I'm wondering whether the uncertainty around tariffs and the impact in terms of the inflationary impact or the inflationary pressure that these tariffs may create really keeps the Fed on the sidelines for perhaps longer than a period that would take us through September.
Our expectation is still in September and you may see enough continued wear and tear on the economy by then that the Fed feels compelled to go ahead and move because they're not necessarily going to wait for hard data to come through.
And by the time we get to September, you will have you'll have a couple more CPI prints, a couple more PPI prints, you'll have some data for the Fed to start looking at.
And we do think you'll see a continued deceleration, if you will.
We're not looking, we don't think it's recessionary, but we do think that you're impacting the strong growth we came into January with.
I want to focus a little bit, if we can, on one industry in particular, artificial intelligence.
Today, Mark Zuckerberg said that Meta is going to be building massive data centers to power AI.
Elon Musk saying that Tesla shareholders will be voting soon on whether to invest in Musk's startup XAI.
And tomorrow in Pennsylvania, President Trump will be announcing a $70 billion investment package that will focus not only on AI but energy generation as well.
Are you still playing this?
And if so, how is that unfolding in your portfolio?
I think it's hard not to play it, if you will, in terms of I mean just owning a plain old index fund and any of the technology names and you're you're at least market weighted if not overweighted in in that play.
And yeah, we do think the combination of that and some of the more progrowth, pro businessfriendly aspects of the one big beautiful bill that was passed last week or the week before, those things do put some nice support underneath.
So that's one of the reasons why we're not out there with a massive recessionary fall.
And that could help surprise relative to employment, too, because you've got tighter labor markets in there.
And if you get some support where companies are hiring again, because they need to hire for construction workers.
They're going to need to pay those workers a little more than they historically have, if you will.
We're going to put up those data centers, leverage AI across a variety of industries, and we don't think it's close to the final innings.
It's definitely in the early innings still in terms of the build out there in much the same way as you're probably in the mid 90s, not the late 90s when we were building out the infrastructure for the internet to begin with.
The other thing that's happened under the Trump administration is this embracing of cryptocurrencies.
House Republicans have declared this week as crypto week.
We've got three bills on the agenda on the House side.
Maybe a regulatory framework begins to emerge and maybe some institutional investor appetite begins to occur around crypto.
And as I'm speaking to you, Carol, Bitcoin is above 120,000, which is hard to believe because when President Trump was elected to his second term, I think Bitcoin was under 70,000.
So, this has been a pretty phenomenal run and I'm curious as to how you're feeling about it.
It's interesting.
It's something we've watched.
It still feels like it's in the speculative zone pieces of it, but build again building out the infrastructure of it, watching it play, having a regulatory framework of it will help.
And I think we need to pick a handful of industries that we want to make sure we stay at the forefront of.
And you know trying to bring some battery technology back whether it's restarting some of the nuclear energy because it's one thing all of this stuff is going to take energy on the grid and we're not going to get there just by pumping oil and drilling coal.
Okay, Carol, we'll leave it there.
Thank you so very much.
Carol Schleif, she is the Chief Market Strategist at BMO Private Wealth joining us here on the Daybreak Asia podcast.
[Music]
Welcome back to the Daybreak Asia podcast.
I'm Doug Krner.
The CEO of Japan's third largest bank says the US will continue to be an important trading partner for Japan even with tariff uncertainty.
Still, Mizuho CEO Masahiro Kihara says Japan will need to diversify away from its second biggest trading partner.
Kihara spoke with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua in London.
Here is part of their conversation.
Mr. Kihara, thank you so much for speaking to us here at Bloomberg.
Now, how confident are you about reaching the ¥1 trillion profit within a few years given all of the global uncertainty and given what we heard on tariffs and trade?
Thank you very much for having me.
Uh, in fact, I think from current earning profile, I think we have almost reached ¥1 trillion actually.
Uh, we had 800 last year, we had 880 billion.
Uh, we took one-time losses around somewhere around 120 billion actually, so I think in reality we reached one trillion thanks for all the you know circumstances.
But what does the uncertainty do the uncertainty surrounding some of the Trump policies and trade and tariffs?
Yes, yes.
So before April 2nd, we were aiming somewhere around ¥1.1 trillion for this year actually.
However, because of all the uncertainties, we uh sort of shrink it down from as a conservative base to uh 950 trillion, uh I'm sorry, 950 billion again.
But I think you know when things get certain the corporate action will come back which means that we can ratchet up a little bit.
Yeah.
Or guidance.
So where are you seeing that uncertainty play into right now?
Is it loans?
Is it chief executives not spending, not deploying cash?
Yes.
Right now the CEOs are very, very on the sidelines actually, but uh but for example if it is a domestic deal even in each region if it is a domestic deal things are happening which means that we don't see a lot of crosswater happening right now.
All of them are we have a big chunk of pipeline but they they're not executed but from a domestically perspective people are moving a little bit.
So I think you know there is a good chance that people will get confident at some point.
You've also built up a US investment bank basically franchise.
How's that going?
So we starting from building the capital markets by oursel we went to equity capital markets.
M&A was missing for us but we purchased Green Hill and I think at this moment we have the necessary pieces on the ground actually.
So I'm very very looking forward to see the synergies between our former Mizuho platform and the Green Hill platform to materialize actually.
But do you plan to take the model of the successful investment bank that you built and actually apply it elsewhere including in Asia?
Yes.
So we would like to uh sort of use our US capabilities transplanted to Europe, Asia and so that the re also even in Japan so that there will be cross regional collaboration between regions and so that and that I think that will bring our next growth actually.
How much of your growth will be organic and how much will be through mergers and acquisitions?
From now on, I think we did the Green Hill deal.
It's very important that we make sure that the synergies will be built out and and and for us the next growth will basically be organic.
Okay.
Because you've said in the past that you weren't used to or you didn't want to for example interested in buying some you know traditional commercial banks with a physical branch network.
So that's still the case.
That's still the case.
But how do you see Mizuho changing actually in the next four to five years?
Yeah.
So I I mean there are a couple of areas that should be interesting for us.
Uh just as I said investment banking regional collaboration that will bring a lot of synergies inside our institution also as as you may know asset management wealth management is growing in Japan and this will be another area and also one of one more area that will be very interesting will be Japanese midcaps actually.
Okay.
So the midcaps are keen to grow or if they cannot grow they they might delist.
And these there are couple many corporate actions happening in that space.
So I think this will be another interesting area for us.
Is competition very fierce in wealth management?
Yes.
Uh it is very a high competitive but but I think the thing is is that the overall market is growing and that is beneficial for all of the banks I think.
Yeah.
And on the midcap is there something specific?
Will it be basically lending that they need or all services as they grow?
There will be advisories.
Yeah.
And also lending.
So both.
How do you see the you know Japanese landscape for businesses changing?
How much will they look?
I mean Japan has been a great experiment right in terms of financials for a long time.
Yes.
Is it companies that will then grow also abroad as the economy stabilizes?
I would say that if right now there's many uncertainties but I think as things get clearer the corporate action will come back.
Uh these couple of years we have seen many corporate actions happening investing outside Japan, you know changing their business portfolio risk, selling parts of the business that they are not doing well so concentrating the areas that have strength banks.
So I I would say that once things get clear corporate action will come back and many you know Japanese corporates will try to invest in outside of Japan too.
Are you confident in the Japanese economy overall?
Overall I think we still have strengths in the economy sectors that we have.
So I think overall we are very I am very confident in that.
Uh the thing is that we we have to concentrate our resources in the area that we have strength.
Uh we have high quality manufacturing, uh high quality you know products.
Uh so I think we need to figure out where the strengths are and try to sell it to the world.
Do you worry or are there dangers actually to Japan given the spike in long-term interest rates?
Yes.
So 20 years, so for the long end, I suppose 20 years, 30 years, there has been spike and there has been volatility but I think the government said that they will try to shift the issuance to a 10 years or below.
I think the BOJ is a little bit shrinking it QT.
I think that will help.
But is there a point


Where it actually starts hurting your business and starts hurting the real economy?

Well, I think uh, BOJ is saying that the neutral rate is somewhere around 1%, to 1.5%. And on top of that, uh, 10 years will be somewhere around 2% to 2.25%. Then I think that that's the level that is uh, okay. But if it goes beyond to 3% or so, that will then hurt the budget, I think.

Are you expecting more turmoil in, you know, in yen, but also not in the bond market?

Not at this moment, actually. I think the current level of 1.4 before 1.5 for 10 years is very uh, it's okay, I think uh, you know, and we have, I, I, I haven't seen any turmoil in the 10 years zone, so as long as the 10 year is fine, I think it's fine.

That is Masahiro Kihara, the CEO of Mizuho, speaking with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua here on the Bloomberg Daybreak: Asia Edition podcast.

[Music]
